Following the [[November 2015 Paris attacks|2015 Paris terror attacks]], the President of Iceland, [[Ólafur Ragnar Grímsson]] announced that he was "shocked to the point of paralysis" to learn from Saudi Arabian Ambassador, that Saudi Arabia planned to donate $1 million to the building of a mosque. Grímsson expressed concern that Saudi Arabian financing of the mosque would fuel radical Islam in Iceland.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://icelandmag.visir.is/article/president-iceland-fears-saudi-arabian-funding-reykjavik-mosque-will-fuel-muslim-extremism |title=President of Iceland fears Saudi Arabian funding of Reykjavík Mosque will fuel Muslim extremism in Iceland |date =24 November 2015 }}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== {{see also | Islam in the United Kingdom}}
According to a report by Anthony Glees, {{#tag:ref|the director of Brunel University's Centre for Intelligence and Security Studies<ref name=donations-teleg/>|group=Note}} extremist ideas being spread allow with donations from Saudi and Arab Muslim sources to British universities. Eight universities, "including [[University of Oxford|Oxford]] and [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]]", accepted "more than £233.5 million from Saudi and Muslim sources" from 1995 to 2008, "with much of the money going to [[Islamic studies|Islamic study centres]]".<ref name=donations-teleg>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1584954/Extremism-fear-over-Islam-studies-donations.html |title='Extremism' fear over Islam studies donations |date =13 April 2008}}</ref>
A 2012 article in [[Arab News]] reported<blockquote>Over the past decade, Saudi Arabia has been the largest source of donations from Islamic states and royal families to British universities, much of which is devoted to the study of Islam, the Middle East and Arabic literature. A large share of this money went toward establishing Islamic study centers. In 2008, Prince [[Al-Waleed bin Talal]] donated £8 million (SR 48.5 million) each to [[Cambridge University|Cambridge]] and [[University of Edinburgh|Edinburgh]] for this purpose, ''[[Al Eqtisadiah]]'' business daily reported yesterday. [[Oxford University|Oxford]] has been the largest British beneficiary of Saudi support. In 2005, Prince Sultan, the late crown prince, gave £2 million (SR 12 million) to the [[Ashmolean Museum]]. In 2001, the King Abdul Aziz Foundation gave £1 million (SR 6.1 million) to the Middle East Center. There are many other donors. Oxford’s £75 million (SR 454.6 million) Islamic Studies Center was supported by 12 Muslim countries. Ruler of [[Oman]], Sultan [[Qaboos bin Said al Said]], gave £3.1 million (SR 18.8 million) to Cambridge to fund two posts, including a chair of Arabic. Ruler of [[Sharjah (emirate)|Sharjah]] [in the [[UAE]]], Sheikh [[Sultan bin Muhammad Al-Qasimi]], has supported [[University of Exeter|Exeter]]’s Islamic studies center with more than £5 million (SR 30 million) since 2001. Trinity Saint David, part of the [[University of Wales]], has received donations from the ruler of [[Abu Dhabi]] Sheikh [[Khalifa bin Zayed Al Nahyan]].<ref name="BURSF-2012">{{cite news|title=British universities receive Saudi funds|url=http://www.arabnews.com/british-universities-receive-saudi-funds|accessdate=23 July 2017|agency=ARAB NEWS|date=30 September 2012}}</ref></blockquote>
In June 2017, following the [[June 2017 London Bridge attack|London Bridge terror attack]], opposition leader [[Jeremy Corbyn]] stated that the "difficult conversations" Prime Minister [[Theresa May]] called for should start with "Saudi Arabia and other Gulf states that have funded and fuelled extremist ideology".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/jeremy-corbyn-saudi-arabia-extremist-funding-terrorism-gulf-states-qatar-isis-al-qaeda-labour-a7773451.html |title=Jeremy Corbyn calls for 'difficult conversations' with Saudi Arabia and Gulf states over extremism funding |date =5 June 2017 }}</ref>
A July 2017 report by the [[Henry Jackson Society]], commissioned by the government of the UK, stated that Middle Eastern nations are providing financial support to mosques and Islamic educational institutions, which have been linked to the spread of extremist material with "an illiberal, bigoted Wahhabi ideology".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-40496778 |title=Saudi Arabia has 'clear link' to UK extremism, report says |date=5 July 2017|work=BBC|accessdate=5 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2017/jul/03/theresa-may-report-foreign-funding-extremists-saudi-arabia |title=Theresa May sitting on report on foreign funding of UK extremists |author=Elgot, Jessica|date=4 July 2017|work=The Guardian|accessdate=5 July 2017}}</ref> The report said that the number of Salafi and Wahhabi mosques in Britain had increased from 68 in 2007 to 110 in 2014.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://themarketmogul.com/extremism-report-puts-saudi-arabia-and-british-pm-may-on-the-spot-strengthens-qatar-in-gulf-crisis/ |title=Saudi Arabian Extremism in the UK: Inside the Henry Jackson Report |author=Dorsey, James M|date=6 July 2017|work=The Market Mogal|accessdate=7 July 2017}}</ref>
==Eastern Europe/Balkans== Historically parts of the [[Balkans]] were introduced to Islam while under the domination of the [[Ottoman Empire]] and have majority or large minority Muslim populations. The [[Revolutions of 1989|fall of Communism]] and [[breakup of Yugoslavia]], provided an opportunity for international Islamic charities to Islamization (or re-Islamization) people who had been living under an irreligious Communist government. Islamic charities—often with the backing of oil-rich Gulf kingdoms—built mosques and madrassas in [[Albania]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.journalpioneer.com/opinion/columnists/2016/8/21/two-albanian-majority-countries-fear-gro-4620907.html|title=Two Albanian-majority countries fear growth of Islamism|date=21 August 2016}}</ref> and other Balkan countries. In [[Bosnia]], Wahhabism is being established particularly in the remote villages.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://sputniknews.com/world/201612231048916831-wahhab-terrorism-daesh-bosnia/ |title=Several Thousand of Wahhabis Present in BiH - Rep. Srpska's Interior Minister |date =23 Dec 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/04/30/muslim-radicals-in-mountain-villages-spark-fears-in-bosnia/ |title=Muslim radicals in mountain villages spark fears in Bosnia |date = 20 April 2016 }}</ref> In [[Kosovo]], Wahhabism is being freely preached and supported by the Saudi government.<ref name = "17May2017">{{cite news|url=http://www.presstv.ir/Detail/2017/05/17/522235/Germany-Wahhabism-Kosovo |title=Germany concerned about spread of Wahhabism in Kosovo |date = 17 May 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://sputniknews.com/europe/201705191053790018-germany-saudi-arabia-kosovo-wahhabism/ |title=Saudi Wahhabi Missionaries and Arab Donors 'Active in Kosovo,' Germany Admits |date =19 May 2017 }}</ref>
===Albania===
A Muslim majority country, Albania had been under anti-clerical communist control for 45 years when the [[Eastern bloc]] fell in 1991. The pro-Islamic [[Democratic Party of Albania|Democratic Party]] was elected to power in 1992, and the government of [[Sali Berisha]] "turned to Saudi Arabia for financial support," and for assistance in "re-Islamizing" the country. Thirty [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]]s and Islamic associations worked toward re-Islamization of Albania, including thirteen of the organizations formed a `Coordination Council of Arab Foundations.` Saudi Arabia sponsored `Al Haramein` and `Musafaq` (which were based in Britain) foundations which "vied" with Islamic organizations from Libya, Sudan, Iran and Turkey in "instumentalization of humanitarian aid as a means of proselytization." At least the Saudi and Sunni Islamist groups preached for creation of an Islamic society "based principally on Wahhabism." Saudi NGOs built 200 mosques and King Fahd of Saudi Arabia donated one million copies of an Albanian language version of the Quran.<ref name=CWDI/>
According to Olivier Roy and Antoine Sfeir, the "organized project undertaken by preachers and Islamic NGOs" was to "expunge indigenous Albanian ideas about Islam, before replacing it with a version of the faith more in conformity with the Wahhabi model. ... Islam in its most radical form was taught as the only true faith, while tolerance was seen as an indication of weakness. ... Hatred of the West was raised to the status of a creed."<ref name=CWDI/>
One of the first Islamists to come to Albania was Muhammad al Zawahiri, (the brother of [[Ayman al Zawahiri]], the leader of the [[Egyptian Islamic Jihad]] movement and [[Osama Bin Laden]]'s key lieutenant) as an accountant for the International Islamic Relief Organization (IIRO). (Unbeknownst to Albanians, in addition to helping with relief and spreading correct Islam, IIRO was charged with the task of helping other members of Islamic Jihad find jobs within "charitable organizations building mosques, orphanages and clinics." By the mid-1980s, the Tirana cell of Islamic Jihad numbered 16 members, including a specialist in false identity documents, a recruit wanted on suspicion of involvement in the attempted assassination. This was later exposed during an investigation carried out by the American and Albanian secret services,<ref name=CWDI>{{cite book|editor1-last=Sfeir|editor1-first=Antoine|title=The Columbia World Dictionary of Islamism|date=2007|publisher=Columbia University Press.|pages=28–30|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rNrMilgHKKEC&pg=PA29&lpg=PA29&dq=albania+iiro&source=bl&ots=Sr_RKq10Jh&sig=oXyMPACaMKslyGTFC4M_9PyPuUM&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Oj8tVd_gMMeZoQT07oCQCQ&ved=0CCQQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=albania%20iiro&f=false|accessdate=14 April 2015}}</ref><ref name=FTCS>{{cite book|editor1-last=Freeman|editor1-first=Michael|title=Financing Terrorism: Case Studies|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lQFhQpE0ye4C&pg=PT248&lpg=PT248&dq=albania+iiro&source=bl&ots=0XEJx0pkc4&sig=vJphjepF44ZUtEsyVC9kr8rbp_Q&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Xz8tVc6FFYn1oAT7-4DgCA&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=albania%20iiro&f=false|accessdate=14 April 2015}}</ref> In June 1998 three Egyptian Islamist accused of terrorist activities were arrested in Albania, with further arrests in September after the [[1998 United States embassy bombings]]. )
How successful the proselytizing has been is unclear. Roy and Sfeir believe that with NGO work in the 1990s "Islamists gained an important foothold",<ref name=CWDI/> however, a 2012 Pew Research study found that only 15% of Muslims surveyed considered religion "a very important factor" in their lives—the lowest percentage in the world amongst countries with significant Muslim populations.<ref name=pew>{{cite web|title=August 9, 2012 Infographic: The World’s Muslims: Unity and Diversity|url=http://www.pewforum.org/2012/08/09/the-worlds-muslims-unity-and-diversity-infographic/|website=pewforum.org|accessdate=14 April 2015|date=9 August 2012|quote=In the 39 countries surveyed, the percentage saying religion is very important to them ranges from 15% in Albania to 98% in Senegal.}}</ref><ref>http://www.pewforum.org/Muslim/the-worlds-muslims-unity-and-diversity-infographic.aspx</ref>
===Bosnia===
During the [[Bosnian War|1992-1995 Bosnian War]], the state of [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] (where the approximately 43% of the population that was Muslim formed the largest religious group) received aid from Saudi groups — [[International Islamic Relief Organization]], Saudi High Commission for Relief, Muwaffaq Foundations — as well as from non-Saudi Islamic groups. A 1996 report by the CIA stated that "all of the major and most of the minor Islamic charities are significant players in the former Yugoslavia", particularly in aiding Bosnian Muslims, delivering food, clothing, and medicine; supporting orphanages, schools, hospitals, agricultural, and refugee camps; and constructing housing, infrastructure. According to the Saudi Embassy to the US, the Saudi Joint Committee for Collection of Donations for Bosnia donated $500 million in aid to Muslims for medical care, refugee camps, education during the Bosnian War, and later reconstruction projects for mosques and religious schools.<ref name="Merdjanova-2013-64">{{cite book|last1=Merdjanova|first1=Ina|title=Rediscovering the Umma: Muslims in the Balkans Between Nationalism and ...|date=2013 |publisher=Oxford University Press |page=64|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6eYRDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA64&dq=Merdjanova+%22collision+over%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi1-e-u--_UAhWj7oMKHQVFAzMQ6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&q=Merdjanova%20%22collision%20over%22&f=false |accessdate=4 July 2017}}</ref> In just one year (1994) Saudi nationals alone gave $150 million through Islamic NGOs for aid to Bosnia. However, a "growing body of reporting indicates that some of these charities are being used to aid Islamic extremist groups that engage in terrorism."<ref name=wikisource-cia>{{cite web|title=CIA Report on NGOs With Terror Links|url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/CIA_Report_on_NGOs_With_Terror_Links |website=wikisource.org|accessdate=14 April 2015}}</ref>
Aid to the local Bosnian Islamist party (the [[Party of Democratic Action|SDA]]) gave it leverage to undermined competing local secular and more traditional Muslim groups.<ref name=CWDI-bosnia/> The SDA prohibited consumption of alcohol and pork, "brought Muslim religious instruction into the schools, opened up prayer rooms, and used the leverage of its distribution of aid to pressurize the population to adopt Muslim names, to wear the veil, and grow beards."<ref name=CWDI-bosnia>{{cite book|editor1-last=Sfeir|editor1-first=Antoine|title=The Columbia World Dictionary of Islamism|date=2007|publisher=Columbia University Press |pages=89–92 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rNrMilgHKKEC&pg=PA89&lpg=PA89&dq=bosnia+IIRO&source=bl&ots=Sr_RKs1-De&sig=3KoGE_bV7ml9U3YEwPWfpz_9G54&hl=en&sa=X&ei=uIwtVYeTE4vsoASSkoHACg&ved=0CEoQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=bosnia%20IIRO&f=false |accessdate=14 April 2015}}</ref><ref name=FTCS>{{cite book|editor1-last=Freeman|editor1-first=Michael|title=Financing Terrorism: Case Studies|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lQFhQpE0ye4C&pg=PT248&lpg=PT248&dq=albania+iiro&source=bl&ots=0XEJx0pkc4&sig=vJphjepF44ZUtEsyVC9kr8rbp_Q&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Xz8tVc6FFYn1oAT7-4DgCA&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=albania%20iiro&f=false|accessdate=14 April 2015}}</ref> A 1992 conference on the protection of human rights in Bosnia brought together representatives from 30 Muslims countries. It passed resolutions declaring "without ambiguity that the aim of the Bosnian conflict was the extermination of Bosnia's Muslims."<ref name=CWDI-bosnia/>
"[[Afghan Arab]]" veterans fighting Serbs in Bosnia as volunteers took upon themselves ''[[Hisbah]]'' ("enjoin good and forbid wrong") including attempting to impose the veil on women and the beard on men. In addition they engaged in <blockquote>causing disturbances in the ceremonies of [Sufi] brotherhoods they deemed to be deviant, .... smashing up cafes, and ... [organizing] sharia marriages to Bosnian girls that were not declared to the civil authorities.<ref name=GKJTPI2002:251>[[#GKJTPI2002|Kepel, ''Jihad'', 2002]]: p.251</ref></blockquote> Rather than spreading strict Islamic practice, these activities were so unpopular with the Bosnian public and media they were condemned by the SDA.<ref name=GKJTPI2002:251/> According to [[Gilles Kepel]], as of 2003, the only thing left of their presence were "a few naturalized Arab subjects married to Bosnian women."<ref name=GKJTPI2002:251/>
From the end of the Bosnian War to 2007, Saudi-financed organizations spent about $700 million in Bosnia, "often in mosques", according to analysts quoted by the New York Times.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/27/world/europe/27islam.html|title=Islamic Revival Tests Bosnia’s Secular Cast|last=Bilefsky|first=Dan|date=2008-12-26|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-06-19|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> "More than half a dozen new madrasas", (religious secondary schools), have been built throughout the country, as have dozens of mosques. In the capital and largest city Sarajevo, Saudi Arabia financed the [[King Fahd Mosque (Sarajevo)|King Fahd Mosque]], a $28 million complex including a sports and cultural center.<ref name=":1" /> According to a former Bosnian intelligence agent (Goran Kovacevic) interviewed by a public television network in the US, ([[PBS]]), the mosque is well financed and "the most radical mosque in the whole Bosnia-Herzegovina. ... All those guys that actually performed some kind of terrorist activity in Bosnia-Herzegovina were part of that mosque".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/is-saudi-funded-mosque-in-sarajevo-threat-to-bosnias-moderate-muslims/ |title=Is Saudi-funded mosque in Sarajevo threat to Bosnia’s moderate Muslims? |work=PBS NewsHour|access-date=2017-06-19|language=en-US}}</ref> In October 2008, eight people were injured when men in hoods attacked participants at a gay festival in Sarajevo, dragging some people from vehicles and beating others while they chanted, “Kill the gays!” and “Allahu Akbar!”<ref name=":1" />
Wahhabi aid organizations also physically influenced Bosnian religious culture following the war. Saudis have helped restore some of the hundreds of mosques and monuments Serb nationalist forces destroyed during the war. While this assistance was badly needed, it involved removing the Islamic calligraphy that adorned many Balkan Muslim tombstones, which Wahhabis considered idolatrous and unIslamic. Critics complain that the graveyards were "often all that was left" of the local Bosnian heritage, and Wahhabis took advantage of Bosnian's desperation.<ref name=Finn-bosnia>{{cite web |last1=Finn |first1=Helena Kane |title=Cultural Terrorism and Wahhabi Islam |url=http://www.cfr.org/world/cultural-terrorism-wahhabi-islam/p5234 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140904022946/http://www.cfr.org/world/cultural-terrorism-wahhabi-islam/p5234 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=4 September 2014 |publisher=Council on Foreign Relations |accessdate=4 August 2014 |ref=October 8, 2002 }}</ref>
===Kosovo=== One country where Saudi Arabia has been particularly successful in spreading strict and conservative Wahhabism where once tolerant local Islam held sway is Kosovo.<ref name="nyt-21-3-2016"/> Following the [[NATO bombing of Yugoslavia|NATO bombing campaign]] of 1999 that helped Muslim Kosovo gain independence from Orthodox Christian Serbia, the Saudi government<ref name="Saudi aid to Kosovo continues">[http://www.saudiembassy.net/1999News/News/ForDetail.asp?cIndex=2076 Saudi aid to Kosovo continues]. Saudi Embassy, 31 October 1999.</ref> and private sources began to provide aid.<ref name="news.bbc.co.uk">Gardner, Frank. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/327453.stm World: Middle East Gulf Arabs aid Kosovo refugees]. [[BBC News]], April 24, 1999.</ref><ref name="Saudi aid to Kosovo continues"/> Saudi citizens donated $20 million to Kosovo in cash as well as food and medical supplies, and the Saudi Red Crescent sent medical volunteers.<ref name="news.bbc.co.uk"/> The Saudi Joint Committee for Collection of Donations for Kosovo and Chechnya sent $45 million for humanitarian relief services (medical care, refugee camps, education, and later reconstruction of mosques and schools) to Kosovo according to the Embassy of Saudi Arabia in the US.<ref name="Merdjanova-2013-64"/>
240 mosques have been built in Kosovo since the 1999 war.<ref name="nyt-21-3-2016"/> The Saudi Joint Committee for Relief of Kosovo and Chechnya built approximately 100 mosques in rural areas, some with Quranic schools adjacent, and sent 388 foreign teachers to spread "their interpretations of Islam".<ref name=Merdjanova-65>{{cite book|last1=Merdjanova|first1=Ina|title=Rediscovering the Umma: Muslims in the Balkans Between Nationalism and ...|date=2013|publisher=Oxford University Press|page=65|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AA6ZsZhwU5oC&pg=PA64&dq=saudi+aid+to+kosovo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=nfxUVYTZKMraoAT_0IDoBw&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=saudi%20aid%20to%20kosovo&f=false|accessdate=14 May 2015}}</ref>
Saudi-sponsored charities sponsored education, classes not only in religion but English and computers, often paying salaries and overhead costs. Families were given monthly stipends. All this was appreciated in the "poor and war ravaged" country but local Kosovar imams complained that stipends were given "on the condition that they attended sermons in the mosque and that women and girls wore the veil". “People were so needy, there was no one who did not join,” according to one Kosovo politician (Ajnishahe Halimi).<ref name="nyt-21-3-2016"/>
According to a critical article by journalist Carlotta Gall, <blockquote>corps of extremist clerics and secretive associations funded by Saudi Arabia and other conservative Arab countries in the Persian Gulf region using an obscure, labyrinthine network of donations from charities, private individuals and government ministries ... [They] transformed this once-tolerant Muslim society at the hem of Europe into a font of Islamic extremism and a pipeline for jihadists.<ref name="nyt-21-3-2016"/></blockquote> Conservatives came to dominate the Islamic Community of Kosovo, the national Islamic organization.<ref name="nyt-21-3-2016"/>
Part of the Wahhabi influence can be found in more strict practices, such as the refusal by some women to shake hands with or talk to male relatives. But threats — or acts — of violence against academics, journalists and politicians have also occurred. One imam in the city of [[Gjilan]], Enver Rexhepi, was "abducted and savagely beaten by masked men" in 2004 after clashing with a Saudi trained student (Zekirja Qazimi) over whether to continue the long-standing practice of displaying the Albanian flag in his (Rexhepi's) mosque. (Qazimi believed the depiction of the dragon on the flag idolatrous.)<ref name="nyt-21-3-2016"/> Kosovo also had "the highest number" of Muslims per capita of any country in Europe leave to fight for [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|ISIL]] in the two years from 2014-2016. Kosovar police have identified 314 people who have left Kosovo to join the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|Islamic State]], "including two suicide bombers, 44 women and 28 children".<ref name="nyt-21-3-2016"/>
After two Muslims from Kosovo killed themselves in suicide bombings in Iraq and Turkey, Kosovo intelligence began an investigation of "sources of radicalism." The Saudi charity Al Waqf al Islami and twelve other Islamic charities were shut down, and 40 people arrested.<ref name="nyt-21-3-2016"/>
Saudi aid has also affected the architecture of Islam in Kosovo, leading to the dismantling of centuries-old Ottoman mosques whose ornamentation was offensive to Wahhabism, including the Hadim Suleiman Aga mosque and Library in Djakovica, Kosovo.<ref name=Archnet>{{cite web|title=Hadim Suleiman Aga Library. Djakovica, Kosovo|url=http://archnet.org/sites/6081|website=Archnet|accessdate=13 May 2015}}</ref> Among the destroyed buildings are "a historic library in Gjakova and several 400-year-old mosques, as well as shrines, graveyards and Dervish monasteries".<ref name="nyt-21-3-2016"/>
According to Carlotta Gall, as of 2016 "Kosovo Central Bank figures show grants from Saudi Arabia averaging €100,000 a year for the past five years", a reduction from the decade earlier, (although payments can be diverted through another country" to obscure their origin and destination"). Picking up the slack in financing "hard-line" Islam have been [[Kuwait]], [[Qatar]] and the [[United Arab Emirates]] — each of which average "approximately €1 million a year" in donations.<ref name="nyt-21-3-2016"/>
===Poland=== [[File:Ośrodek Kultury Muzułmańskiej 03.jpg|thumb|"The Centre of a Muslim Culture" (pl. Ośrodek Kultury Muzułmańskiej) was built in 2015 in Warsaw.]] Although the majority Catholic country has an Islamic population of roughly only 0.1%,<ref name="opendemocracy.net">[https://www.opendemocracy.net/can-europe-make-it/kasia-narkowicz-konrad-pedziwiatr/why-are-polish-people-so-wrong-about-muslims-in OpenDemocracy: Why are Polish people so wrong about Muslims in their country?]</ref> it's indigenous Muslim population of [[Lipka Tatars]] (1,916 per 2011 census)<ref>{{cite web|title=Ludność. Stan i struktura demograficzno-społeczna - NSP 2011|url=http://www.stat.gov.pl/cps/rde/xbcr/gus/LUD_ludnosc_stan_str_dem_spo_NSP2011.pdf|language=pl-PL}}</ref> only nominally adheres to Sunni Islam. However, together with an immigration of refugees and foreign students from Muslim majority countries, the ideology of Wahhabism/Salafism started taking roots in the country, whilst coming in conflict with the Tatar's tolerant and inclusive view of the faith. A Saudi donor Shaykh Abdullatif al Fozan (ranked 51 in 2013 on the Forbes' list of richest Arabs<ref>{{cite web|title=Forbes:The World Richest Arab 2013|url=http://www.forbesmiddleeast.com/en/list/the-world-richest-arab-2013/item/51/language=en-EN}}</ref>) sponsored (4,000,000 euro)<ref>{{cite web|title=Muslims in Visegrad|url=http://www.alfpolska.org/public/editor/file/aktualnosci/Muslims%20in%20central%20europe.pdf|language=en-EN}}</ref> the construction of the "Center of a Muslim Culture" in Warsaw. The building is fully equipped; has a store, a restaurant, library, prayer hall and even a gym. While officially promoting (Sunni) Islam, the Center spreads Wahhabism/Salafism. Originally, it was meant to be built as a "Centre of Arabic Studies" adjacent to the [[University of Warsaw]], but the University's staff refused the offer due to the Saudi funding and the Wahhabi message it would propagate.<ref>http://www.rp.pl/artykul/458934-Meczet--ktorego-nie-chcial-Uniwersytet-Warszawski.html#ap-4</ref>
==Africa== {{See also | Islam_in_Africa#Salafism}}
===East Africa===
Saudi leaders have endeavoured to influence, trade, resources in [[Sudan]], [[Kenya]] and [[Ethiopia]] which has also resulted in a regional rivalry between Sunni Muslim Saudi Arabia and Shia Muslim Iran. The spread of Wahhabism, is a, "key concern of the west, and of many local players as well".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/sep/12/middle-east-scramble-power-east-africa-sudan-kenya-ethiopia |title=Middle East’s leaders cross the Red Sea to woo east Africa |date = 12 September 2016}}</ref>
=== Sudan === [[Sudan]], a poor country with a majority Muslim Arab population whose coastline lies just across the [[Red Sea]] from the [[Hijaz]] province of Saudi Arabia, has had close relations with the kingdom since the [[1973 oil crisis|Arab Oil Embargo]]. However, the dominant interpretation of [[Islam in Sudan]] was very different from that of Saudis or Muslim Brotherhood.<ref name="GKJTPI2002:177">[[#GKJTPI2002|Kepel, ''Jihad'', 2002]]: p.177</ref> Traditional popular Islam of the [[Sufi]] or mystical brotherhoods (the [[Ansar (Sudan)|Ansar]] and the [[Khatmiya]]) who were each attached to a political party,<ref>the [[Umma Party (Sudan)|Umma Party]] for Ansar and the [[Democratic Unionist Party (Sudan)|Democratic Unionist Party]] for Khatmiya</ref> had great influence among the masses of Muslims. Saudi funding, investment, and labor migration from Sudan has all worked over time to change that.
Saudi provided funding for the Muslim Brotherhood<ref name=MERIP>{{cite web|last1=Bernal|first1=Victoria|title=Migration, Modernity and Islam in Rural Sudan |url=http://www.merip.org/mer/mer211/migration-modernity-islam-rural-sudan |website=Middle East Research and Information Project |accessdate=25 June 2014 |ref=Summer 1999}}</ref> whose local leader, [[Hassan al-Turabi]], enjoyed "close relations" with "some of the more conservative members of the Saudi royal family".<ref name="Natsios-85">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wuffMW1e5BwC&pg=PA84&dq=offshoot+of+the+Sudanese+branch+of+the+Muslim+Brotherhood,+the+Islamic+Charter+Front&hl=en&sa=X&ei=90g4Ve_JBszUoASk8oDAAw&ved=0CCcQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=offshoot%20of%20the%20Sudanese%20branch%20of%20the%20Muslim%20Brotherhood%2C%20the%20Islamic%20Charter%20Front&f=false|title=Sudan, South Sudan, and Darfur: What Everyone Needs to Know|date=2012|publisher=Oxford University Press.|pages=85–6|last1=Natsios|first1=Andrew S.|accessdate=22 April 2015}}</ref>
In the fall of 1977, an Islamic bank with 60% of its start up capital coming from Saudi Arabia opened a branch in Sudan.<ref>Moussa Yaqoub, ''Muhammad Faysal Al Saoud: malamih min tajriba al iqtissadiyya al islamiyya'' (Aspects of Experience in the Islamic Economy) (Jeddah: Saudi Publishing and Distributing House, 1998), esp. pp.54-55, 60, quoted in Kepel, Gilles, ''Jihad'', 2002, p.180</ref> By the mid-1980s this bank ([[Faisal Islamic Bank of Sudan]]) was second biggest in Sudan in terms of money held on deposit.<ref name="GKJTPI2002:180">[[#GKJTPI2002|Kepel, ''Jihad'', 2002]]: p.180</ref> Shortly after another similar bank (Al Baraka Bank) was founded. Both provided rewards for whose affiliated with Hassan al-Turabi's Islamist [[National Islamic Front]]—employment and wealth as a reward for young militant college graduates and low interest loans for investors and businessmen unable to find loans elsewhere.<ref name="GKJTPI2002:180" />
In 1983 Saudis persuaded then-President [[Gaafar Nimeiry]] to institute [[sharia]] law<ref name="MERIP" /> including interest-free Islamic banking. The traditional Sudanese banking system was abolished and afterwards <blockquote>any enterprise that needed capital had to be part of Turabi's network to gain access to financial markets. Over time, this has concentrated economic power in the old families from the "Three Tribes" who were loyal to the new regime"<ref name="Natsios-90">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wuffMW1e5BwC&pg=PA84&dq=offshoot+of+the+Sudanese+branch+of+the+Muslim+Brotherhood,+the+Islamic+Charter+Front&hl=en&sa=X&ei=90g4Ve_JBszUoASk8oDAAw&ved=0CCcQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=offshoot%20of%20the%20Sudanese%20branch%20of%20the%20Muslim%20Brotherhood%2C%20the%20Islamic%20Charter%20Front&f=false|title=Sudan, South Sudan, and Darfur: What Everyone Needs to Know|date=2012|publisher=Oxford University Press.|pages=90|last1=Natsios|first1=Andrew S.|accessdate=22 April 2015}}</ref></blockquote>and who have "transformed themselves into Islamists."
The influx of Sudanese labor migrants to Saudi as truck drivers, electricians, factory workers and sales clerks, was also significant. By 1985, according to one source, about 2/3 of the professional and skilled Sudanese workers were employed outside the Sudan, many in the Gulf States.<ref name=eprism>{{cite web|last1=Warburg|first1=Gabriel R.|title=THE MUSLIM BROTHERHOOD IN SUDAN: FROM REFORMS TO RADICALISM*|url=http://www.e-prism.org/images/Muslim_BROTHERS.PRISM.pdf|website=e-prism.org|publisher=THE PROJECT FOR THE RESEARCH OF ISLAMIST MOVEMENTS (PRISM)|accessdate=28 April 2015|date=August 2006}}</ref> (As of 2013 there were 900,000 Sudanese migrant workers in Saudi Arabia.)<ref name="ST-6-11-13">{{cite news|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article48701|title=300,000 Sudanese expat workers could face deportation from Saudi Arabia: report|date=6 November 2013|publisher=sudan tribune|accessdate=2 May 2015}}</ref>
Looking at the change in religious practices of a village in northern Sudan over a five-year period from 1982 to 1988, anthropology researcher Victoria Bernal found labor migration of villagers to Saudi Arabia "were catalysts for change, stimulating the rise of `fundamentalist` Islam in the village". Returning migrants "boldly" critiqued the Islamic authenticity of local practices such as "mourning rituals, wedding customs and reverence for holy men in particular." More well-to-do villagers were "building high brick or cement walls around their homes", women began wearing ankle-length robes. Traditional wedding rituals with singing and mixing of genders were called into question.<ref name="MERIP" />
"Adopting fundamentalist practices" had become a "way to assert one’s sophistication, urbanity and material success." <ref name="MERIP" /> Migrant workers also formed connections with, and helped finance, the Muslim Brotherhood affiliated [[National Islamic Front]] political party which could remit their salaries back home to families in Sudan evading taxation in exchange for a percentage (that was less than the taxation).<ref name="eprism2">{{cite web|url=http://www.e-prism.org/images/Muslim_BROTHERS.PRISM.pdf|title=THE MUSLIM BROTHERHOOD IN SUDAN: FROM REFORMS TO RADICALISM*|date=August 2006|website=e-prism.org|publisher=THE PROJECT FOR THE RESEARCH OF ISLAMIST MOVEMENTS (PRISM)|last1=Warburg|first1=Gabriel R.|accessdate=28 April 2015}}</ref> Saudi helped found the African Islamic Center (later the [[International University of Africa]]) to help train African Muslim preachers and missionaries "with the [[Salafist]] view of Islam."<ref name="GKJTPI2002:181">[[#GKJTPI2002|Kepel, ''Jihad'', 2002]]: p.181</ref>
As [[Hassan al-Turabi]] and his National Islamic Front grew in influence and in 1989 a coup d'état by [[Omar al-Bashir#Presidency|Omar al-Bashir]] against an elected government negotiating to end the war with the animist and Christian South established Sudan as the first Sunni Islamist state. Al-Turabi became the "power behind the throne" of the al-Bashir government from 1989-1999.<ref name="turabi-hrw">{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/legacy/press/2002/03/turabi-bio.htm|title=Biography of Hassan al Turabi|website=Human Rights Watch|accessdate=4 November 2014}}</ref> The revivalist tenure in power was not as successful as its influence on banking or migrant workers. International organizations alleged war crimes, ethnic cleansing, a revival of slavery, torture of opponents, an unprecedented number of refugees fleeing country,<ref name="jstor">{{cite journal|last2=Lobban|first2=Richard|date=Spring 2001|title=THE SUDAN SINCE 1989: NATIONAL ISLAMIC FRONT RULE|jstor=41858370|journal=Arab Studies Quarterly|volume=23|issue=2|pages=1–9|last1=Fluehr-Lobban|first1=Carolyn}}</ref> and Turabi and allies were expelled from power in 1999. The jihad in the south ended unsuccessfully with the south seceding from Sudan (forming [[South Sudan]]) taking with it nearly all of Sudan's oil fields.<ref name="Bariyo">{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/sudans-al-bashir-wins-presidential-election-1430134646|title=Sudan’s Bashir Wins Presidential Election in Vote Boycotted by Opposition|date=April 27, 2015|agency=Wall Street Journal|last1=Bariyo|first1=Nicholas|accessdate=27 April 2015}}</ref> Turabi himself reversed earlier Islamist positions on marriage and inequality in favor of liberal positions, leading some conservatives to call him an apostate.<ref name="ST-4-2006">{{cite news|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article15219|title=Sudan’s Turabi considered apostate|date=24 April 2006|agency=Sudan Tribune|accessdate=27 April 2015}}</ref><ref name="packer">{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2006/09/11/060911fa_fact1|title=The Moderate Martyr: A radically peaceful vision of Islam|last=Packer|first=George|date=11 September 2006}}</ref> Al Jazeera estimates that as of 2012 10% of Sudanese are tied to Salafi groups, (more than 60% of Sudanese are affiliated with Sufism), but that number is growing.<ref name="sharif">{{cite web|url=http://studies.aljazeera.net/en/reports/2012/07/20127395530326675.htm|title=Salafis in Sudan:Non-Interference or Confrontation|last=Al Sharif|first=Jamal|publisher=AlJazeera Center for Studies|work=03 July 2012|accessdate=7 April 2013}}</ref>
===Egypt=== Muslim Brethren who became wealthy in Saudi Arabia became key contributors to Egypt's Islamist movements.<ref name=GKJTPI2002:51>[[#GKJTPI2002|Kepel, ''Jihad'', 2002]]: p.51</ref><ref>David Sagiv, ''Fundamentalism and Intellectuals in Egypt, 1973-1999'', (London: Frank Cass, 1995), p.47</ref> Many of Egypt's future ''[[ulama]]'' attended the [[Islamic University of Madinah]] in Saudi which was established as an alternative to the Egyptian government-controlled [[Al-Azhar University]] in Cairo. [[Muhammad Sayyid Tantawy]], who later became the grand mufti of Egypt, spent four years at the Islamic University.<ref>Judith Miller, ''God has Ninety-Nine Names: Reporting from a Militant Middle East'', (New York: Touchstone Books, 1996), p.79</ref> Tantawy demonstrated his devotion to the kingdom in a June 2000 interview with the Saudi newspaper Ain al-Yaqeen, where he blamed the "violent campaign" against Saudi human rights policy on the campaigners' antipathy towards Islam. "Saudi Arabia leads the world in the protection of human rights because it protects them according to the ''sharia'' of God."<ref name=Murawiec-56>{{cite book|last1=Murawiec|first1=Laurent|title=Princes of Darkness: The Saudi Assault on the West|date=2003, 2005|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|page=56|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eLPGIj0XShkC&pg=PA56&dq=al-Azhar+saudi&hl=en&sa=X&ei=zrYdVf-TC867ogT024H4CA&ved=0CCcQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=al-Azhar%20saudi&f=false|accessdate=2 April 2015}}</ref>
Saudi funding to Egypt's al-Azhar center of Islamic learning, has been credited with causing that institution to adopt a more religiously conservative approach.<ref name=miller>{{cite book|last1=Miller|first1=Judith|title=God Has Ninety-Nine Names: Reporting from a Militant Middle East|date=1996|publisher=Simon and Schuster|page=79|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tH_ThgVEoAcC&pg=PA541&dq=god+has+99+names+judith+miller&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_LQdVZajGtGpogSDjoDwBA&ved=0CCYQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=al-azhar&f=false|quote=Almost two decades of such Saudi funding had made the state's largest Islamic institution even more conservative. Many ulema had worked in Saudi Arabia, among them Mufti Tantawi, Egypt's chief sheikh, who had spent four years at the Islamic University of Medina. |accessdate=2 April 2015}}</ref><ref name=Abdelnasser1994>{{cite book|last1=Abdelnasser|first1=Walid|title=Islamic Movement In Egypt|origyear=1994|year=2011|publisher=Routledge|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QUrFBQAAQBAJ&pg=PT68&dq=al-Azhar+saudi&hl=en&sa=X&ei=zrYdVf-TC867ogT024H4CA&ved=0CCEQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=al-Azhar%20saudi&f=false|chapter=The Attitudes Towards Selected Muslim Countries|quote=... it is important to refer to the position of Shikh `Abdil-Halim Mahmud (d.1978) Shikh of al-'Azhar ... towards Saudi Arabia. Shikh Mahmud had an ideological affinity with the Saudi interpretation of Islam. Due to his links with Saudi Arabia, he moved loser to al-Ikhwan al-Muslimum. This position contrasted with the position of al-`Azhar in the 1960s...}}</ref>
=== Algeria === Political Islam and/or salafist "Islamic revivalism" became dominant and the indigenous "popular" or Sufi Islam found in much of North Africa greatly weakened, in large part because of the 1954-1962 [[Algerian War]]—despite the fact the victorious [[National Liberation Front (Algeria)|National Liberation Front]] (FLN) was interested in socialism and Arab nationalism, not political Islam.
Diminishing indigenous Islam was the dismantling of Sufi mystical brotherhoods and the confiscation and redistribution of their land in retaliation for their lack of support for the FLN during the [[Algerian War|fight against the French]].<ref name="GKJTPI2002:166">[[#GKJTPI2002|Kepel, ''Jihad'', 2002]]: p.166</ref> Strengthening revivalism was a campaign of Arabization and Islamization by the government (FLN) to suppress the use of the French language (which was still dominant in higher education and the professions), to promote Algerian/Arab identity over residual French colonial culture. To do this Egyptians were recruited by the Algerian state to Arabize and de-Frenchify the school system. Like Saudi Arabia, Algeria saw an influx of Egyptian [[Muslim Brotherhood]] members hired to teach Arabic and eager to escape government suppression. While the leftist FLN Algerian government was totally uninterested in Islam as a foundation for conducting worldly affairs (as opposed to building a national identity), the Muslim Brotherhood teachers very much were, and many of the generation of "strictly Arabphone teachers" trained by the Brothers adopted the beliefs of their teachers and went on to form the basis of a "Islamist intelligentsia".<ref name="GKJTPI2002:162-3">[[#GKJTPI2002|Kepel, ''Jihad'', 2002]]: p.162-3</ref>
In addition, in the 1980s, as interest in Islam grew and devotion to the ruling [[National Liberation Front (Algeria)|National Liberation Front]] (FLN) party and secular socialism waned in Algeria, the government imported two renowned Islamic scholars, [[Mohammed al-Ghazali]] and [[Yusuf al-Qaradawi]], to "strengthen the religious dimension" of the "nationalist ideology" of the FLN. This was less than successful as the clerics supported "Islamic awakening", were "[[fellow traveler]]s" of the [[Muslim Brotherhood]], supporters of Saudi Arabia and the other Gulf monarchies, and had little interest in serving the secularist FLN government.<ref name="GKJTPI2002:165">[[#GKJTPI2002|Kepel, ''Jihad'', 2002]]: p.165</ref>
Also in the 1980s, several hundred youth left Algeria for the camps of [[Peshawar]] to fight [[Afghan Arabs|jihad in Afghanistan]]. As the FLN government was a close ally of the jihadists' enemy, the [[Soviet Union]], these fighters tended to consider the fight against the Soviets a "prelude" to jihad in Algeria.<ref name="GKJTPI2002:164">[[#GKJTPI2002|Kepel, ''Jihad'', 2002]]: p.164</ref>
When the FLN followed the example of post-Communist Eastern European government and held elections in 1989, the main beneficiary was the massively popular [[Islamic Salvation Front]] (FIS) political party which sought to establish [[sharia]] law in Algeria. "Islamist intelligentsia" formed its leadership, FIS second in command, [[Ali Belhadj]], was a state school teacher and a prime example or this.<ref name="GKJTPI2002:162-3">[[#GKJTPI2002|Kepel, ''Jihad'', 2002]]: p.162-3</ref> The Saudis supporting the party,<ref name="ORFPI1994:1192">[[#ORFPI1994|Roy, ''Failure of Political Islam'', 1994]]: p.119</ref> and the Front's other co-leader [[Abbassi Madani]] received much aid from Saudi Arabia and other oil monarchies. (This did not prevent him from coming out in support of [[Sadam Hussein]]—along with most other Islamists—when Saddam [[Invasion of Kuwait|invaded Kuwait]], despite the adamant fear of and opposition to [[Saddam Hussein]] by the Gulf oil states.)<ref name="GKJTPI2002:172-3">[[#GKJTPI2002|Kepel, ''Jihad'', 2002]]: p.172-3</ref>
After the FLN saw how unpopular it was and canceled the elections, a bloody civil war broke out. The Salafist-jihadis returning to Algeria supported the FIS and later provided military skill in the [[Armed Islamic Group of Algeria]] (GIA).<ref name="GKJTPI2002:164" />
The [[Algerian Civil War]] ended badly with an estimated 200,000 Algerians, many of them civilians, killed. FIS did not recover from the war, but by 2002 another strict/conservative Islamic force—Salafism—began to emerge.<ref name="Boukhars" /> To end the war, the government needed help disarming the Islamists fighters and were able to enlist the Salafis—apolitical and nonviolent<ref name="Boukhars" />—as a religious counterweight and to use their religious influence to persuade the Islamists to stop fighting. In return the government has shown tolerance towards the Salafis.<ref name="Chikhi-10-8-10" /> Culturally, as of 2010 Salafis have exerted "a growing influence over society and how people dress, deal with the state and do business" in Algeria. Their putative quietism notwithstanding they have protested a government plan to make women remove their headscarves for passport photographs, pressuring shopkeepers to stop selling tobacco and alcohol.<ref name="Chikhi-10-8-10">{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-algeria-religion-salafism-idUSTRE6791TQ20100810|title=Hard-line Islam steps out of shadows in Algeria|date=10 August 2010|agency=Reuters|last1=Chikhi|first1=Lamine|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref><ref name="Boukhars">{{cite web|url=http://carnegieendowment.org/2015/11/24/quietist-and-firebrand-salafism-in-algeria-pub-62075|title=‘Quietist’ and ‘Firebrand’ Salafism in Algeria|website=carnegie endowment|last1=Boukhars|first1=Anouar|accessdate=20 October 2016}}</ref> In June 2010, a group of Salafist clerics attending an official function along with the minister of religious affairs showed their rejection of modern political systems as an illegitimate innovation or "''[[bid‘ah]]''" by refusing to stand for the national anthem.<ref name="Chikhi-10-8-10" /> Salafist Sheikh Abdelfettah Zeraoui explains criticism of Salafism as the work of Western powers who have pressured Muslim governments "to crack down on the Salafi current because it represents the pure Islam."<ref name="Chikhi-10-8-10" /> The Salafis connection with Saudi Arabia includes Saudi Grand Mufti, Sheikh [[Abdul-Aziz ibn Abdullah Al ash-Sheikh|Abdul-Aziz al-Sheikh]] who has endorsed opposition to international regulations requiring photographs for passports show a person's forehead and ears even if they are a woman. Abdelmalek Ramdani—the most prominent Salafist imam in Algeria—lives in Saudi Arabia, and prominent Salafist preachers—including Ali Ferkous, Azzedine Ramdani and Al Eid Cherifi—received religious training in Saudi Arabia.<ref name="Chikhi-10-8-10" />
=== West Africa === The [[Izala Society]]—a Wahhabi missionary group established 1978—has become one of the largest Islamic societies in Nigeria, [[Chad]], [[Niger]], and [[Cameroon]].<ref name="amara">{{cite web|url=http://www.sharia-in-africa.net/pages/staff/amara.php|title=Sharia Debates in Africa|last=Ben Amara|first=Ramzi|work=circa 2007|accessdate=22 May 2014}}</ref> Izala is funded by Saudi Arabia and led by the World Muslim League. It fights what it sees as the ''[[bid’a]]'', (innovation), practiced by the [[Sufi]] brotherhoods,<ref name="Paden-28">{{cite book|title=Faith and Politics in Nigeria|last=Paden|first=John N.|date=2008|publisher=US Institute of Peace Press|page=28}}</ref> specifically the [[Qadiriyya|Qadiri]] and [[Tijaniyya|Tijan]] Sufi orders.<ref name="SSI-Hill-18">{{cite book|url=http://www.strategicstudiesinstitute.army.mil/pdffiles/pub989.pdf|title=SUFISM IN NORTHERN NIGERIA: FORCE FOR COUNTER-RADICALIZATION?|last=Hill|first=Jonathan N. C.|date=May 2010|publisher=Strategic Studies Institute|page=18}}</ref> It is very active in education and [[Dawah|Da‘wa]] (propagation of the faith) and in Nigeria has many institutions all over the country and is influential at the local, state, and even federal levels.<ref name="amara" />
== Central Asia and Caucasus == Scholar [[Vitaly Naumkin|Vitaliĭ Vi͡acheslavovich Naumkin]] argues that even before the fall of Communism, Saudi Arabia had substantial influence on Islam in Central Asia because of its prestige as the location of the [[Hajj|holy places of Hejaz]], its financial resources and because of the large number of Central Asian pilgrims (and their descendants) who had gone to Saudi on [[hajj]] and decided to stay.<ref name="Naumkin-2005-38">{{cite book|last1=Naumkin|first1=Vitaliĭ Vi͡acheslavovich|title=Radical Islam in Central Asia: Between Pen and Rifle|date=2005|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|page=38|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5vwxP3gPUkMC&pg=PA37&dq=Islamic+Movement+of+Uzbekistan&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwilmpq12PzUAhUm24MKHYZ-A1EQ6AEIQDAF#v=onepage&q=Islamic%20Movement%20of%20Uzbekistan&f=false |accessdate=9 July 2017}}</ref>
During the [[Soviet–Afghan War]], thousands of Soviet Central Asians were drafted into the Soviet Army to fight their co-religionists (and sometimes fellow ethics), the Afghan Mujahideen. As Islam and Central Asian peoples had been repressed by the Soviets—often brutally<ref name="Rashid, 2002-01-14"/>—many were "deeply affected by the dedication" of their putative enemies. "Hundreds of Uzbek and Tajik Muslims travelled secretly to Pakistan and Saudi Arabia to study in madrasahs or to train as guerrilla fighters against the Soviets in Afghanistan." Many of these were influenced by the idea of armed jihad taught at Deobandi madrasahs in Pakistan where "places specifically for Central Asian radicals, who arrived without passports or visas and received a free education and a living allowance."<ref name="Rashid, 2002-01-14"/> Wahhabism also made headway thanks to Saudi funding and Saudi-trained preachers. In the late 1980s, as the same time the Soviets were starting to withdraw from Afghanistan there was "an explosion of interest" in Islam in Central Asia. "Thousands of mosques were built, Qurans and other Islamic literature were brought in from Saudi Arabia and Pakistan and distributed free among the population."<ref name="Rashid, 2002-01-14"/>
In Central Asia the term "Wahhabism" has evolved from its original meaning of followers of [[Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab]], to become 'agitprop invective' and a ‘polemic foil in sectarian arguments' used against Islamic "reformists and ‘troublesome Muslim opponents’", or even against "any and all expressions of nontraditional Islam’.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://factsanddetails.com/central-asia/Central_Asian_Topics/sub8_8f/entry-4523.html|title=RELIGION AND ISLAM IN CENTRAL ASIA {{!}} Facts and Details|last=Hays|first=Jeffrey|website=factsanddetails.com|language=en|access-date=2017-07-06}}</ref>
=== Afghanistan === Saudi and Islamist forces helped the Afghan Mujahideen in their struggle against the Soviets, with Saudi Arabian government providing approximately $4 billion in aid to the mujahidin from 1980-1990.<ref name=DGHK2003:127>[[#DGHK2003|Gold, ''Hatred's Kingdom'', 2003]]: p.127</ref> Saudi Arabia and other [[Arab states of the Persian Gulf]] became "important backers" for Islamic schools (''madrassas'') for Afghan refugees in Pakistan which appeared in the 1980s near the Afghan-Pakistan border.<ref name=PJCJS>Jessica Stern, "[http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/56633/jessica-stern/pakistans-jihad-culture Pakistan's Jihad Culture]" ''Foreign Affairs'', November–December 2000</ref> In 1988, the Muslim World League stated that it had opened 150 Quran study centers and 85 Islamic schools for Afghan refugee students in Peshawar, a short distance across the border in Pakistan.<ref name="kepel-396">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tttzgNKFAI8C&printsec=frontcover&dq=kepel+jihad&hl=en&sa=X&ei=rtolVcOlMY60oQSu04C4AQ&ved=0CCMQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=kepel%20jihad&f=false|title=Jihad|date=2002|page=396|quote=[note24]|last1=Kepel|first1=Gilles}}</ref>
Many were radical schools sponsored by the Pakistan [[Jamiat Ulema-e-Islam (F)|JUI]] religious party and became "a supply line for jihad" in Afghanistan.<ref name=PJCJS/> According to analysts the ideology of the schools became "hybridization" of the [[Deobandi]] school of the Pakistani sponsors and the Salafism supported by Saudi financers.<ref name=GKJTPI2002:223>[[#GKJTPI2002|Kepel, ''Jihad'', 2002]]: p.223</ref><ref>Ahmed Rahid, ''Taliban'', p.90</ref>
Many of the [[Taliban]] were graduates of these schools.<ref name="Matinuddin, Kamal 1999 pp.25">Matinuddin, Kamal, ''The Taliban Phenomenon, Afghanistan 1994–1997'', [[Oxford University Press]], (1999), pp. 25–6</ref> (Eight Taliban government ministers came from one school, Dar-ul-Uloom Haqqania.<ref>Ahmed Rashid, ''Taliban'', p.90</ref>) While in power, the Taliban implemented the "strictest interpretation of [[Sharia|Sharia law]] ever seen in the [[Muslim world]]."<ref>Rashid,''Taliban,'' (2000), p.29</ref><ref name="Maley">Dupree Hatch, Nancy. "Afghan Women under the Taliban" in Maley, William. ''Fundamentalism Reborn? Afghanistan and the Taliban''. London: Hurst and Company, 2001, pp. 145-166.</ref>
After the Taliban came to power the Saudis helped them in a number of ways. Saudi Arabia was one of only three countries (Pakistan and United Arab Emirates being the others) officially to recognize the Taliban as the official government of Afghanistan before the 9/11 attacks, (after 9/11 no country recognized it). King Fahd of Saudi Arabia “expressed happiness at the good measures taken by the Taliban and over the imposition of shari’a in our country," During a visit by the Taliban’s leadership to the kingdom in 1997.<ref>Algar, Hamid, ''Wahhabism: A Critical Essay'', p.57.</ref>
Saudi Wahhabism practices, influenced the Taliban. One example was the [[Committee for the Promotion of Virtue and the Prevention of Vice (Saudi Arabia)|Saudi religious police]], according to Rashid. <blockquote> `I remember that all the Taliban who had worked or done hajj in Saudi Arabia were terribly impressed by the religious police and tried to copy that system to the letter. The money for their training and salaries came partly from Saudi Arabia.`</blockquote> The taliban also practiced [[Public executions in Saudi Arabia|public beheadings]] common in Saudi Arabia. Ahmed Rashid came across ten thousand men and children gathering at Kandahar football stadium one Thursday afternoon, curious as to why (the Taliban had banned sports) he "went inside to discover a convicted murderer being led between the goalposts to be executed by a member of the victim's family." <ref name=lacey-200-police>{{cite book|last=Lacey|first=Robert|title=Inside the Kingdom : Kings, Clerics, Modernists, Terrorists, and the Struggle for Saudi Arabia|date=2009|publisher=Viking |pages=200–1 |quote=`I remember` says Ahmed Rashid, `that all the Taliban who had worked or done hajj in Saudi Arabia were terribly impressed by the religious police and tried to copy that system to the letter. The money for their training and salaries came partly from Saudi Arabia.` Ahmed Rashid took the trouble to collect and document the Taliban's medieval flailings against the modern West, and a few months later he stumbled on a spectacle that they were organizing for popular entertainment. Wondering why ten thousand men and children were gathering so eagerly in the Kandahar football stadium one Thursday afternoon, he went inside to discover a convicted murderer being led between the goalposts to be executed by a member of the victim's family. }}</ref>
The Taliban's brutal treatment of Shia Muslims, and the destruction of [[Buddhas of Bamiyan#Attacks on the Buddha.27s statue|Buddhist statues in Bamiyan Valley]] may also have been influenced by Wahhabism, which had a history of attacking and [[takfir]]ing Shia, while prior to this attack Afghan Sunnis had never persecuted their Shia minority.<ref name=DGHK2003:133>[[#DGHK2003|Gold, ''Hatred's Kingdom'', 2003]]: p.133</ref>{{dubious|date=August 2018}} (see [[Abdur Rahman Khan]] and [[1888–1893 Uprisings of Hazaras]]).
Another activity Afghan Muslims had not engaged in before this time was destruction of statues. In 2001, the Taliban dynamited and rocketed the nearly 2000-year-old statues Buddhist Bamiyan Valley, which had been undamaged by Afghan Sunni Muslim for centuries prior to then. Mullah Omar declared "Muslims should be proud of smashing idols. It has given praise to Allah that we have destroyed them."<ref>{{cite book |author=Markos Moulitsas Zúniga |coauthors= |title=American Taliban: How War, Sex, Sin, and Power Bind Jihadists and the Radical Right |year=2010 |publisher=Polipoint Press |quote= | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1Cdx6yTUFxIC&pg=PA8&lpg=PA8&dq=%22Muslims+should+be+proud+of+smashing+idols%22&source=bl&ots=Hl1nwYSxkK&sig=rG9zIIyemmmJytx4C5aP6fpP8Js&hl=en&ei=D_niTJ6OK8SjnQfH6-zWDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CEoQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=%22Muslims%20should%20be%20proud%20of%20smashing%20idols%22&f=false |isbn=1-936227-02-9 }}</ref>
===Uzbekistan===
The leadership of the [[Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan]] (IMU) has been influenced by the Wahhabi and Deobandi traditions. IMU head, [[Juma Namangani]], (who was killed in November 2001) was indirectly influenced by outside Islamic revival when serving in the [[Soviet–Afghan War|Soviet army in Afghanistan]] fighting Afghan mujahideen. He was radicalized by the experience and returning to his home in the [[Fergana Valley]] wanting to fight on the side of the Islamic revival not against it. He associated with local Islamists of the [[Islamic Renaissance Party of Tajikistan|Islamic Renaissance Party]] (IRP) and the local Islamic revolutionary party ''Adolat'' ({{lang-en|Justice}}),<ref name="Rashid, 2002-01-14">{{cite magazine|last=Rashid |first=Ahmed |date=14 January 2002 |title=They're Only Sleeping: Why militant Islamicists in Central Asia aren't going to go away |url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2002/01/14/theyre-only-sleeping |dead-url=no |magazine=[[The New Yorker]] |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6f6GZzyJo?url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2002/01/14/theyre-only-sleeping |archive-date=6 February 2016 |access-date=6 February 2016 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> and became a founder of the [[Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan]].<ref name="Rashid, 2002-01-14"/> In 1995, Namangani traveled to Saudi Arabia to undergo "religious and intelligence training from Saudi intelligence".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ismor.com/cornwallis/cornwallis_2005/CX_2005_11-Baranick-CX-July%2012.pdf |title=Addressing Terrorist Threats in Azerbaijan and Uzbekistan: Winning Hearts and Minds|last1=Salayeva|first1=Rena|last2=Baranick |first2=Michael J. |date=|website=ismor.com|page=196|access-date=}}</ref> According to journalist Ahmed Rashid, the IMU <blockquote>is believed to have been funded by Saudis, Pakistanis, Turks, Iranians, and Osama bin Laden. Namangani was one of the most important “foreign Taliban” commanders in northern Afghanistan during the recent fighting there. He led a pan-Islamic force of Uzbeks, Tajiks, Pakistanis, Chechens, and Uighurs from Xinjiang province in China. They fought on the side of the Taliban in Afghanistan, but their long-range goal was to establish an Islamic state throughout Central Asia.<ref name="Rashid, 2002-01-14"/></blockquote>
=== Caucasus === Wahhabism or Salafism has been particularly successful in the ex-Soviet Muslim-majority areas such as [[Dagestan]] and [[Chechnya]] for a number of reasons, according to [[Robert Bruce Ware]]. * Wahhabi funding, institutions, and missionaries are particularly useful because they fill the gap left by the collapse of the [[USSR]], where traditional Islamic leaders were relatively unknowledgeable, and accustomed to surviving by subservience;<ref name="Ware-91-2" /> * Wahhabism fills the ideological void left by the collapse of socialism;<ref name="Ware-91-2" /> * the Wahhabi adversarial role toward non-Wahhabi government (i.e. Russia's) fills the traditional role of Islam toward the Russian government and * it takes advantage of public resentment against the existing corrupt and incompetent governments which traditional Islamic leaders are tainted by;<ref name="Ware-91-2" /><ref name="RMSARI-quote">{{cite journal|last2=Ehrmann|first2=Maya|date=Fall 2013|title=The Rise of Militant Salafism in Azerbaijan and Its Regional Implications|url=http://www.mepc.org/journal/middle-east-policy-archives/rise-militant-salafism-azerbaijan-and-its-regional-implications?print|journal=Middle East Policy Council|volume=XX|issue=3|quote=The initial introduction of Salafism to Azerbaijan was due to outside influence; however, its evolution and radicalization within Azerbaijan is a local phenomenon that, besides the Dagestan-based Northern Caucasian insurgency, has been influenced rather weakly by outside factors. Foremost, conservative people have cited the deterioration of traditionalist values in Azerbaijan and come to perceive Islam as a symbol of local (ethnic) cultural revival. Furthermore, Azerbaijanis have increasingly turned to Salafism as an ideological alternative of political opposition to the current regime.|last1=Souleimanov|first1=Emil|accessdate=22 May 2015}}</ref> * advocacy of sharia law and organized Wahhabi enforcement of it plays into the desire for protection against post-Soviet criminal predation and the arbitrary brutality of the police.<ref name="Ware-91-2">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5VPfBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA90&lpg=PA90&dq=dagestan+saudi&source=bl&ots=NjNObQCWIr&sig=hs04iRXgyaPq7OEyylm8MoIbPOM&hl=en&sa=X&ei=QiNeVYefNImoogTW9IDoCg&ved=0CEcQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=dagestan%20saudi&f=false|title=Dagestan: Russian Hegemony and Islamic Resistance in the North Caucasus|date=2010, 2015|publisher=Routledge.|location=NY|pages=91–2|last1=Ware|first1=Robert Bruce|accessdate=21 May 2015}}</ref> ;Azerbaijan Although two-thirds of Azerbaijanis are members of the Shiite branch of Islam,<ref name="RMSARI">{{cite journal|last2=Ehrmann|first2=Maya|date=Fall 2013|title=The Rise of Militant Salafism in Azerbaijan and Its Regional Implications|url=http://www.mepc.org/journal/middle-east-policy-archives/rise-militant-salafism-azerbaijan-and-its-regional-implications?print|journal=Middle East Policy Council|volume=XX|issue=3|last1=Souleimanov|first1=Emil|accessdate=22 May 2015}}</ref> (which Wahhabis/Salafis strongly oppose), and Muslims in Azerbaijan have a tradition of secularism, Wahhabism/Salafism has made headway among the one third of the country that identify themselves as Sunni Muslims and primarily inhabit the northern and western regions,<ref name="RMSARI" /> specifically those of Dagestani ethnicity (Avars, Lezgins, Tsakhurs, Rutuls) in areas bordering Dagestan.
Wahhabism/Salafism was introduced and catalyzed starting with the dissolution of the Soviet Union by missionaries and funds from Arab countries such as Kuwait and Saudi Arabia,<ref name="RMSARI" /> and Salafists mainly from Chechnya and Dagestan. In 1997, the Azerbaijani branch of the Kuwaiti Revival of Islamic Heritage society, built the Abu Bakr mosque in [[Baku]], the capital. It became "one of the most successful mosques" in Azerbaijan, with 5000 people typically attending Friday prayer (compared to 300 for an average Azerbaijan mosque)<ref name="WIBBSMB">{{cite journal|date=September 2, 2008|title=Who is Behind the Bombing of the Salafi Mosque in Baku?|url=http://www.jamestown.org/single/?no_cache=1&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=5128#.VV9HdvzF-ZM|journal=Terrorism Focus|volume=5|issue=31|last1=Valiyev|first1=Anar|accessdate=22 May 2015}}</ref> and the "myriad" of social opportunities it provided created an "attractive network for its relatively young believers," and was "a great impetus for the Salafi movement".<ref name="RMSARI" /> Its Imam for many years (Gamat Suleymanov) was a graduate of the Islamic University of Madinah of [[Medina]] Saudi Arabia.<ref name="WIBBSMB" />
;Chechnya [[File:Vakhkhabi mosque.jpg|thumb|right|300px | Wahhabi Mosque in Duisi, [[Pankisi Gorge]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]]] Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov has said, that the spread of Wahhabism must be contained noting the need to, "crack down on the ideology of Wahhabism" in mosques, on TV, on social networks, through mobile devices.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://tass.com/politics/941624|title=Chechnya’s leader, top cleric discuss struggle against terrorist ideology|date=16 April 2017}}</ref> ;Dagestan Wahhabi or Islamist insurgency in the North Caucasus is "particularly intense" in Dagestan.<ref name="afp-2015">{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/world/2015/03/22/Russian-forces-kill-seven-terror-suspects-in-Dagestan-.html|title=Russian forces kill seven terror suspects in Dagestan|date=22 March 2015|agency=AFP|accessdate=21 May 2015}}</ref> As of 2011, Suicide bombers were killing an average of three policemen per week, with numerous civilians also becoming casualties. From January to June 2011, Police claimed to have killed 100 "rebels" according to Russian Interior Ministry officials.<ref name="clash">{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/news/world/europe/in-russias-dagestan-salafi-muslims-clash-with-government-authorities#full|title=In Russia's Dagestan, Salafi Muslims clash with government authorities|publisher=The National|work=14 September 2011|accessdate=7 May 2013}}</ref> ; Georgia Although Georgia is predominantly Christian, it has Muslim minorities. In the [[Pankisi Gorge]], home to the Kists, a small Muslim ethnic group, the older generation of Sufis is gradually giving away to younger Wahhabis who "scorn" the old practices and pray in "new, gleaming mosques".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2015/10/georgians-remote-valley-joining-isil-151020082321188.html|title=Why Georgians in a remote valley are joining ISIL|date=21 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.balcanicaucaso.org/eng/Areas/Georgia/Pankisi-the-land-of-the-offspring-174711|title=Pankisi, the land of the offspring|date=17 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=6258|title=Saakashvili Warns Over "Wahhabism Threat" in Georgia|date=17 February 2004}}</ref> Wahhabism entered into "a dozen Pankisi villages in the 1990s, popularized by young people educated in Arab countries". (The "Wahhabis" do not use the term but agree they are practicing a form of Sunni Islam "similar to that which prevails in Saudi Arabia.)<ref name="TOL">{{cite news|url=http://www.tol.org/client/article/21739-a-growing-gap-in-pankisi-gorge.html|title=A Growing Gap in Pankisi Gorge|date=25 August 2010|agency=Transitions Online|last2=Kochiashvili|first2=Marika|last1=Chitanava and|first1=Eka|accessdate=20 May 2015}}</ref> According to a 2015 report, "a year ago, about 70 per cent" of the younger generation were Wahhabis and "now almost 90 per cent of them are."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.opendemocracy.net/od-russia/inga-popovaite/radicalisation-in-georgia-self-fulfilling-prophecy|title=Radicalisation in Georgia: a self-fulfilling prophecy?|date=23 October 2015}}</ref>
==South Asia== Wahhabism is being exported into South Asia through the funding of mosques, Islamic schools, cultural institutions and social services.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.eurasiareview.com/30072016-creating-frankenstein-the-impact-of-saudi-export-of-ultra-conservatism-in-south-asia-analysis/|title=Creating Frankenstein: The Impact Of Saudi Export Of Ultra-Conservatism In South Asia – Analysis|date=30 June 2016}}</ref> With "public and private Saudi funding", Wahhabism has "steadily gained influence among Muslim communities" in South Asia since the late 1970s, "significantly" changing "the nature" of South Asian Islam, and bringing an increase in "Islamist violence" in "Pakistan, Indian Kashmir, and Bangladesh".<ref name="Pillalamarri2">{{cite journal|last=Pillalamarri|first=Akhilesh|date=20 December 2014|title=The Radicalization of South Asian Islam: Saudi Money and the Spread of Wahhabism|url=http://georgetownsecuritystudiesreview.org/2014/12/20/the-radicalization-of-south-asian-islam-saudi-money-and-the-spread-of-wahhabism/|journal=Georgetown Security Studies Review|accessdate=10 November 2015}}</ref> According to [[Jammu and Kashmir]] Police and Indian Central intelligence officers, in 2005 the [[House of Saud]] approved a $35-billion (Rs 1,75,000 crore) plan to build mosques and madrassas in South Asia.<ref name="Asit" />
===Bangladesh=== {{See also |Bangladesh–Saudi Arabia relations}} Bangladesh has the forth or fifth largest [[Islam by country|population of Muslims]] of any country and about a 30% poverty rate.<ref name="Factbook" /> Since the late 1970s, Saudi Arabia has funded the construction of thousands of radical mosques and madrasas in Bangladesh. [[Hefazat-e-Islam Bangladesh|Hefazat-e-Islam]], controls over 14,000 mosques and madrasas where up to 1.4 million students get an Islamic education without any state supervision.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ucanews.com/news/how-saudi-arabia-finances-radical-islam-in-bangladesh/79312 |title=How Saudi Arabia finances radical Islam in Bangladesh |date =29 May 2017 }}</ref> individuals radicalized in Wahhabi-funded mosques have coalesced under Hefazat-e-Islam, which was implicated in a January 2014 incident when its members took to the streets in violent protests and demanded the implementation of Islamic law in Bangladesh.<ref>“Anarchy at the Ballot Box: Bangladesh Rising,” Vice News, April 15, 2014, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PMgykLxfAwU#t=469.</ref>
In 2013 when the Bangladeshi government cracked down on Jamaat-e Islami for war crimes during the Bangladesh liberation war, Saudi Arabia expressed its displeasure by cutting back on the number of Bangladeshi guest workers allowed to work in (and sent badly needed remittances from) Saudi Arabia.[55]
Bangladesh also receives a concession from Saudi on the price of oil imports. With the concession has come changes in religious practices, according to Imtiyaz Ahmed, a religious scholar and professor of International Relations at [[University of Dhaka]].<ref name="dw-hijab">{{cite news|url=http://www.dw.de/petro-islam-on-the-rise-in-bangladesh/a-6552859-1|title='Petro-Islam' on the rise in Bangladesh|date=2011-06-20|quote="Many women have started wearing black Middle Eastern burqas, as it makes them feel 'safer'. [according to Imtiyaz Ahmed, a religious scholar and professor of International Relations at Dhaka University]|accessdate=23 March 2014|newspaper=DW}}</ref> "Saudi Arabia is giving oil, Saudi Arabia would definitely want that some of their ideas to come with oil." The [[Milad (celebration)|Milad]], the celebration of the Prophet Muhammad’s birthday and formerly "an integral part of Bangladeshi culture" is no longer popular, while black burqas for women are much more so .<ref name="dw-2">{{cite news|url=http://www.dw.de/petro-islam-on-the-rise-in-bangladesh/a-6552859-1|title='Petro-Islam' on the rise in Bangladesh|date=2011-06-20|accessdate=23 March 2014|newspaper=DW}}</ref> In Saudi Arabia Milad is officially ignored, while for women in public places all-covering black (or similar dark, dull color) hijab is required.
One way conservative Saudi religious practices are spread is through schools. Nearly 6 million Bangladeshi children attend schools at (private) Quomi madrassas. Unlike regulated state schools these madrasses are free and entirely supported by private donations, which come from both inside and outside Bangladesh.<ref name="BBC-funding">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-13603338|title=Bangladesh plans $100m madrassa reform programme|last=Ethirajan|first=Anbarasan|publisher=BBC News|quote=Qaumi madrassas are financed by donors from inside Bangladesh and abroad.|work=31 May 2011|accessdate=5 April 2014}}</ref> {{#tag:ref|A report examining "the political consciousness of madrassa teachers and graduate students in Bangladesh," found that 70 of 77 respondents at madrassas replied Saudi Arabai when asked "Which country is the best friend of Bangladesh?"<ref>[http://www.iiu.edu.pk/wp-content/uploads/downloads/ird/downloads/Islamic-Education-in-Bangladesh-Third-Year-Report.pdf Views from the Madrassa: Islamic Education in Bangladesh] Mumtaz Ahmad, Table 4, p.53.)</ref>|group=Note}} Quomi madrassas syllabus follows "orthodox Islamic teaching", being "restricted to study of [[Hadith]] and [[Tafsir]]-e-Quran (understanding and interpretation of Hadith and Quran) with emphasis on aspects of Jihad"<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bangladeshlivenews.com/home/article-details/2079/column/Reforming+Qaumi+Madrassas+of+Bangladesh/|title=Reforming Qaumi Madrassas of Bangladesh {{!}} Bangladesh Live News|last=|first=|date=2013|website=www.bangladeshlivenews.com|access-date=2017-06-28}}</ref>
One burka-wearing Bangladeshi told the DW journalist who interviewed Imtiyaz Ahmed that she started wearing a burqa because at her son's school (a Quomi madrassas) "the teachers scold the students whose mothers don’t wear burqas. So, I asked my nephew who works in the Middle East to get me one."<ref name="dw-2" /> While rising crime and desire to feel safe are factors in the popularity of burkas, religious pressure is also. <!----Saudi Arabia has promised to donate $1 billion to set up 560 Wahhabi mosques across [[Islam in Bangladesh|Bangladesh]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2017/05/10/saudis-budget-1b-for-bangladesh-mosque-project.html |title=Saudis budget $1B for Bangladesh mosque project |date=10 May 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.benarnews.org/english/news/bengali/mosques-project-04282017155127.html |title=Bangladesh Embarks on Building 560 Mosques with Saudi Financial Aid |date = 28 April 2017}}</ref><ref name = "Asia1">{{cite news|url=http://www.dailyexcelsior.com/threat-to-national-security/ |title=Threat to National Security |date =1 May 2017 }}</ref> Awaiting resolution http://www.benarnews.org/english/news/bengali/mosque-update-05122017164246.html ---->
===India=== Between 2011 and 2013, 25,000 Saudi clerics arrived in India with $250 million to build mosques and universities and to hold seminars.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://theweek.com/articles/570297/how-saudi-arabia-exports-radical-islam |title=How Saudi Arabia exports radical Islam |date = 8 April 2015 }}</ref> There is concern regarding the increasing Saudi-Wahhabi influence in the North West and in the East of [[Islam in India|India]].<ref name=bad-news>{{cite web|url=http://scroll.in/article/712341/why-a-saudi-award-for-televangelist-zakir-naik-is-bad-news-for-indias-muslims |title=Why a Saudi award for televangelist Zakir Naik is bad news for India’s Muslims|last1=Daniyal |first1=Shoaib |date=10 March 2015|accessdate=2013-12-03}}</ref><ref name="Asia1">{{cite news|url=http://www.dailyexcelsior.com/threat-to-national-security/ |title=Threat to National Security |date =1 May 2017 }}</ref>
According to Saudi diplomatic cables released by [[WikiLeaks]] in 2015, 140 Muslim preachers are listed as on the Saudi Consulate’s payroll in New Delhi alone.<ref name="nyt-21-3-2016">{{cite news|last1=GALL|first1=CARLOTTA|title=How Kosovo Was Turned Into Fertile Ground for ISIS |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/22/world/europe/how-the-saudis-turned-kosovo-into-fertile-ground-for-isis.html |accessdate=1 July 2017|agency=New York Times|date=21 May 2016}}</ref>
In the Indian state of [[Jammu and Kashmir]] (a majority-Muslim state that has been the site of the [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1947]], the [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1965]], the [[Kargil War|1999 Kargil War]], and the ongoing [[Insurgency in Jammu and Kashmir|insurgency]]), 1.5 of the 8 million Muslims "affiliate with Wahhabi mosques" thanks to Saudi influence.<ref>Tariq Mir, “[http://pulitzercenter.org/projects/kashmir-india-pakistan-sufi-wahhabi-islam Kashmir: The Rise of a Hard Faith],” Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting, December 13, 2011</ref><ref name="Pillalamarri">{{cite journal | url=http://georgetownsecuritystudiesreview.org/2014/12/20/the-radicalization-of-south-asian-islam-saudi-money-and-the-spread-of-wahhabism/ |title=The Radicalization of South Asian Islam: Saudi Money and the Spread of Wahhabism |journal=Georgetown Security Studies Review |date= 20 December 2014 |last= Pillalamarri |first=Akhilesh | accessdate=10 November 2015 }}</ref> The Saudi-funded [[Ahl al-Hadith#South Asia|Jamiat Ahl-e-Hadith]] has built 700 mosques and 150 schools in JK and claims that 16 percent of Kashmir’s population are members.<ref name="Asit">Asit Jolly, “[http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/saudi-charities-pump-in-funds-through-hawala-channels-to-radicalise-kashmir-valley/1/165660.html The Wahhabi Invasion],” ''India Today'', December 23, 2011.</ref><ref name="Pillalamarri" /> Police in Jammu and Kashmir believe this is the result of a $35 billion plan approved by Saudi Arabia’s government in 2005 to build mosques and madrassas in South Asia.<ref name="Asit" />
===Maldives=== In the late 1990s Wahhabism challenged more tradition moderate practices of [[Islam in the Maldives]]. After the 2004 tsunami, Saudi funded preachers gained influence. Within a short period of a decade fundamentalist practices dominated the culture.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/asia-pacific/tourists-blissfully-unaware-of-islamist-tide-in-maldives-1.1898425|title=Tourists blissfully unaware of Islamist tide in Maldives|date=16 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/26/paradise-jihadis-maldives-islamic-extremism-syria|title=Paradise jihadis: Maldives sees surge in young Muslims leaving for Syria|date=26 February 2015}}</ref> It is reported that Maldives has a, "growing Wahhabist majority and an autocratic government . . . or, according to the Maldivian opposition, a pliant ally where few questions are asked and fewer are allowed".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.climatechangenews.com/2017/03/05/saudis-make-maldives-land-grab-secure-oil-routes-china/ |title=Saudis make Maldives land grab to secure oil routes to China |date =3 March 2017 }}</ref> In 2017, Members of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] have raised concerns that the decision by the government of President [[Abdulla Yameen]] to "sell" one of Maldives 26 atolls, to Saudi Arabia will aggravate Wahhabism in the [[Maldives]].<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.presstv.ir/Detail/2017/03/03/512844/Maldives-Saudi-Arabia-India-Maldivian-Democratic-Party-King-Salman-Faafu |title= Maldivian opposition warns against atoll sale to Saudi Arabia|date = 3 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.wionews.com/south-asia/it-is-difficult-to-see-how-the-chinese-could-do-anything-other-than-control-the-maldives-ex-maldives-president-15290 |title=It is difficult to see how the Chinese could do anything other than control the Maldives: Ex-Maldives president |date =7 May 2017 }}</ref>
According to Azra Naseem, a Maldivian researcher on extremism at Dublin City University, “you can’t say all of Salafism is radical Islam, but it’s a form of Islam that’s completely brought into the Maldives from Saudi Arabia and other places. Now, it’s being institutionalized, because everybody in the universities, in the Islamic Ministry, they are all spreading this form of Islam.”<ref name=":02">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/18/world/asia/maldives-islamic-radicalism.html|title=Maldives, Tourist Haven, Casts Wary Eye on Growing Islamic Radicalism|last=Schultz|first=Kai|date=2017-06-18|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-06-19|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> In April 2017, Yameen Rasheed, a liberal blogger and "a strong voice against growing Islamic radicalization", was stabbed to death "by multiple assailants".<ref name=":02" /> According to a study by the Soufan Group, the islands supply 200 fighters to extremist outfits in Syria and Iraq<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://soufangroup.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/TSG_ForeignFightersUpdate3.pdf|title=FOREIGN FIGHTERS: An Updated Assessment of the Flow of Foreign Fighters into Syria and Iraq|last=|first=|date=December 2015|publisher=THE SOUFAN GROUP|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref>—the world’s highest per-capita number of foreign fighters.<ref name=":02" />
